recipes.name: South Indian Fish Curry
ingredients: 1 large brown onion, halved and thinly sliced
2 medium green chilies, deseeded and finely chopped
2 cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated
750 g firm white fish fillets (such as flake or ling), cut into 4 cm pieces
1 Lebanese cucumber, halved, deseeded, and chopped
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
directions: Step 1: Heat the vegetable oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat.
Step 2: Add the mustard seeds and cook for 30 seconds, or until the seeds begin to pop.
Step 3: Add the sliced onion, crushed garlic, curry leaves, and fish stock to the pan.
Step 4: Cover and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Then, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, for 6 minutes, or until the onions are softened.
Step 5: While the onions are cooking, deseed and finely chop the green chilies and peel and finely grate the ginger.
Step 6: Stir the chopped chilies, grated ginger, ground coriander, cumin seeds, and ground turmeric into the onion mixture. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute, or until aromatic.
Step 7: Stir in the fish pieces and coconut milk. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat.
Step 8: Reduce heat to low, partially cover, and cook, stirring gently occasionally, for 5 minutes, or until the fish flakes easily with a fork.
Step 9: In a small bowl, combine the yogurt and chopped cucumber.
Step 10: Season the curry with salt and pepper to taste.
Step 11: Serve the curry immediately with the yogurt-cucumber mixture, cooked basmati rice, and pappadums.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant South Indian fish curry, bathed in soft, directional light emphasizing the rich ochre broth and flaky white fish. Style in a rustic terracotta bowl, garnished with fresh curry leaves and a drizzle of coconut milk.  Compose with a shallow depth of field, focusing on a succulent piece of fish, against a dark, textured background. Incorporate a few scattered mustard seeds and sliced green chilies. Aim for a warm, inviting mood highlighting the aromatic spices and freshness of the ingredients.  Shoot from a slightly overhead angle to showcase both the curry's texture and the fish pieces.

video_script.title: South Indian Fish Curry

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a finished South Indian Fish Curry served with basmati rice, pappadums, and a cucumber-yogurt mixture. The curry should look creamy and inviting with visible pieces of fish and spices.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making a fragrant and creamy South Indian Fish Curry. It's packed with flavor and surprisingly easy to make.

scenes.image_prompt: Show all ingredients laid out and labeled
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: firm white fish fillets, onion, garlic, ginger, green chilies, curry leaves, coconut milk, yogurt, cucumber, and spices like mustard seeds, cumin, coriander, and turmeric.  We'll also need fish stock, vegetable oil, and basmati rice for serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of mustard seeds popping in hot oil in a saucepan.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a tablespoon of vegetable oil in a saucepan. Add mustard seeds and let them pop. This releases their wonderful aroma.

scenes.image_prompt: Onions, garlic, and curry leaves being sautéed in the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Add sliced onions, crushed garlic, and curry leaves to the pan with the fish stock. Cover and cook for about 6 minutes until softened.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped chilies, grated ginger, ground coriander, cumin seeds, and ground turmeric being added to the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Now, stir in chopped green chilies, grated ginger, ground coriander, cumin seeds, and turmeric. Cook for a minute until fragrant.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish pieces and coconut milk added to the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Gently add your fish pieces and coconut milk. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat and simmer for 5 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.

scenes.image_prompt: Yogurt and chopped cucumber being mixed in a bowl.
scenes.voice_over: While the fish simmers, combine yogurt and chopped cucumber in a bowl. This cooling side complements the curry beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: Final shot of the South Indian Fish Curry served with rice, pappadums and the cucumber-yogurt mixture.  Steam should be rising from the curry.  Close-up on the curry with a spoon dipping into it.
scenes.voice_over: Season the curry with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot with the cucumber-yogurt mixture, fluffy basmati rice, and crispy pappadums.

scenes.image_prompt: Text overlay with nutritional information: Calories, Protein, Carbs, and Fat.
scenes.voice_over: Per serving, this curry has approximately 400 calories, 30 grams of protein, 25 grams of carbs, and 20 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat coconut milk.
Adjust the amount of chili to your preferred level of spiciness.
If you don't have fish stock, you can substitute with water or vegetable stock.
Leftovers can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

recipes.name: Baked Barramundi Pilaf with Tikka Masala
ingredients: 450g frozen barramundi fish fillets, thawed and cut into 2.5cm pieces
Pappadums or naan bread, for serving
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 190°C (170°C fan-forced). Combine chicken stock powder and boiling water in a jug and stir until dissolved.
Step 2: Heat olive oil in a large, heavy-based, oven-safe casserole dish over medium heat.
Step 3: Add chopped onion and cook, stirring, for 3-4 minutes, or until softened.
Step 4: Add tikka masala curry paste and stir for 1 minute, or until fragrant.
Step 5: Add basmati rice and stir to coat in the curry paste.
Step 6: Pour in 3 cups of the prepared stock mixture and bring to a boil.
Step 7: Cover the dish and transfer to the preheated oven.
Step 8: Bake for 20 minutes.
Step 9: Remove from oven and stir in the barramundi pieces, frozen peas, and the remaining stock.
Step 10: Return the covered dish to the oven and cook for another 10 minutes, or until the fish is just cooked through.
Step 11: Gently stir in the baby spinach, cover, and set aside for 3-5 minutes, or until the spinach has wilted.
Step 12: Serve hot with pappadums or naan bread.

Style the pilaf with vibrant green spinach and peas interspersed with flaky barramundi pieces.  Use soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the texture of the rice and fish. recipes.name: Fish Makhani (Indian Butter Fish)
ingredients: 1 kg firm white fish fillets, skin removed, cut into 2-inch pieces
400g canned chopped tomatoes, divided (half pureed, half chopped)
directions: Step 1: Marinate the fish: In a large, non-metallic bowl, combine the fish fillets, lime juice, salt, and red chili powder. Cover and marinate for 1 hour.

Step 2: Roast and grind spices: Heat a flat pan or griddle over medium heat. Gently roast the cloves, peppercorns, cinnamon stick, bay leaves, and almonds, stirring frequently, until they darken slightly. Remove from heat, cool, and add the cardamom seeds. Grind into a coarse powder using a clean, dry coffee grinder.

Step 3: Marinate the fish with yogurt mixture: In a bowl, combine the yogurt, ground spice mixture from Step 2, coriander powder, cumin powder, and turmeric powder. Add this mixture to the marinated fish. Cover and marinate for another hour.

Step 4: Sear the fish: Heat the vegetable oil in a large pan or skillet over medium-high heat. Add the marinated fish pieces and sear until sealed and opaque, turning gently. Remove the fish from the pan and set aside.

Step 5: Prepare the sauce: In the same pan, add the pureed tomato paste and chopped tomatoes. Cook for a few minutes, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes soften. Add the fish stock and dried fenugreek leaves. Bring to a simmer.

Step 6: Combine fish and sauce: Return the seared fish to the pan with the tomato sauce. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer gently for 10-15 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and the gravy has thickened slightly. Stir occasionally, being careful not to break the fish.
Step 7: Finish and serve: Melt the butter in a small pan and pour it over the fish makhani. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with naan bread, rice, or a salad.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Fish Makhani in a rustic, earthenware bowl, nestled amongst warm naan bread. The fish, glistening with buttery sauce, should be the focal point with a shallow depth of field.  Garnish with fresh cilantro and a lime wedge. Utilize warm, diffused lighting to highlight the rich orange hue of the sauce and texture of the fish. The background should be dark and moody, with subtle textures to add depth.  The overall mood should be inviting and appetizing.

scenes.voice_over: Combine the yogurt with the ground spices, coriander powder, cumin, and turmeric. Add this mixture to the fish and marinate for another hour.

scenes.voice_over: Heat vegetable oil in a pan and sear the marinated fish pieces until opaque. This helps to lock in the moisture and create a nice texture.

scenes.voice_over: Add the pureed and chopped tomatoes to the same pan and cook until softened. Then add the fish stock and fenugreek leaves. Bring to a simmer.

scenes.voice_over: Gently add the seared fish back to the tomato sauce. Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 10-15 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and gravy thickens slightly. Stir occasionally.

cooking_tips: Use firm white fish like cod, haddock, or halibut for best results.
Adjust the amount of red chili powder to control the spiciness.
Don't overcook the fish, as it can become dry.
If the gravy becomes too thick, add a little more fish stock or water to adjust the consistency.

recipes.name: Vietnamese Fried Fish Noodle Soup (Bún Cá Chiên)
ingredients: 1 lb fish bones or heads (mild, white-fleshed fish)
1 tsp fish sauce (or more, to taste)
2 large ripe tomatoes, cut into wedges
1 lb fish fillet (mild, white-fleshed fish), thinly sliced
Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste
directions: Step 1: Rinse the fish bones or heads under cold running water. Rub generously with 1 tbsp of coarse salt, then rinse again thoroughly.

Step 2: In a large pot, combine the fish bones or heads, 3-4 cups of water, 1/2 tsp salt, and smashed ginger. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 30-40 minutes, skimming off any foam or impurities that rise to the surface.

Step 3: While the broth simmers, prepare the other ingredients. Cut the tomatoes into wedges. Slice the fish fillet thinly at an angle (about 1/4-inch thick). Season the fish slices with salt and pepper.
Step 4: After 30-40 minutes, taste the fish broth and adjust seasoning if needed. Discard the fish bones and ginger. Add the tomato wedges and fish sauce to the broth.
Step 5: Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions. Drain and set aside.

Step 6: Lightly dust the fish slices with all-purpose flour. Heat vegetable oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat. Fry the fish slices in batches until golden brown and crispy, about 2-3 minutes per side. Remove from pan and drain on paper towels.
Step 7: Taste the broth again and adjust seasoning with fish sauce or water as needed.
Step 8: Divide the cooked noodles among serving bowls. Top with the fried fish slices, fresh dill, cilantro, and sliced scallions. Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant bowl of Bún Cá Chiên, showcasing crispy fried fish fillets against a backdrop of translucent rice noodles submerged in a rich, golden broth.  Garnish with fresh dill, sliced green onions, and red chili flakes. Utilize natural, bright lighting to highlight the texture of the fish and the steam rising from the broth.  Focus on the crispy edges of the fish, with a shallow depth of field blurring the background. Compose the shot from a slightly overhead angle, showcasing the colorful tomatoes and herbs in the broth, creating a fresh, inviting mood. Include chopsticks and a small bowl of lime wedges as props.  Background should be rustic wood or textured linen.

recipes.name: Fisherman's Soup with Potatoes and Roasted Garlic Sauce
ingredients: 1 kg Assorted Fish (Trout, Mackerel, Zander fillets, Pike pieces)
directions: Step 1: Making the Fish Broth: In a large pot, combine the fish heads and tails, chopped carrots, onion, parsnip, celeriac, tomato, half of the red bell pepper, and hot pepper. Cover with 2 liters of water, bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30 minutes.

Step 2: Straining and Preparing the Broth: Strain the broth, reserving the liquid. Pick any desirable fish flesh from the bones and set aside. Reserve the cooked carrots and bell pepper, dicing them into small cubes for later use.
Step 3: Second Strain: Strain the broth again through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth for a clearer soup.

Step 4: Adding Potatoes and Aromatics: Return the strained broth to the clean pot. Add the peeled potatoes (halved if large) and bring to a boil. Add the diced remaining red bell pepper. Cook for 15 minutes, or until the potatoes are almost tender.

Step 5: Adding Fish and Seasoning: Add the assorted fish (halving larger pieces as needed) to the pot. Season with 1-2 teaspoons of salt and 3-5 tablespoons of white wine vinegar. Simmer for 5-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through but still tender.

Step 6: Tempering and Adding Egg Mixture: In a small bowl, whisk together the egg and smetana/crème fraîche. Slowly drizzle two ladles of hot soup into the egg mixture, whisking constantly to temper. Pour the tempered mixture into the soup, stirring gently. Remove from heat immediately. Add the reserved fish pieces and diced vegetables.
Step 7: Final Seasoning and Herbs: Adjust seasoning with salt, pepper, and additional vinegar to taste. Stir in the chopped lovage or parsley just before serving.

Step 8: Making the Roasted Garlic Sauce: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Wrap garlic cloves in foil and roast for 30-40 minutes, or until soft and fragrant. Once cool enough to handle, squeeze roasted garlic into a small bowl. Add a pinch of salt and slowly whisk in the vegetable oil. Add about 1/2 cup of cold water and mix well. Adjust consistency with more water if desired.

video_script.title: Fisherman's Soup with Roasted Garlic Sauce

scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making Fisherman's Soup, a comforting dish packed with flavor. It's easier than you think!

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients for the fish broth arranged on a wooden table: salmon, pike, and trout heads and tails, carrots, onion, parsnip, celeriac, tomato, red bell pepper, and a small hot pepper.
scenes.voice_over: For the broth, we'll need the heads and tails of salmon, pike, and trout, along with carrots, onion, parsnip, celeriac, tomato, red bell pepper, and a small hot pepper for a touch of heat.

scenes.image_prompt: Large pot with fish heads, tails and vegetables covered in water. Simmering on a gas stove with bubbles on the surface.
scenes.voice_over: Combine all broth ingredients in a large pot, cover with 2 liters of water, and bring to a boil.  Reduce heat and simmer gently for 30 minutes. This will extract maximum flavor from the fish and vegetables.

scenes.image_prompt: Chef's hands are carefully picking edible fish meat off the bones and setting it aside in a separate bowl. Strained broth is in a pot in the background.
scenes.voice_over: Strain the broth and pick any desirable fish flesh from the bones. Reserve the cooked carrots and bell pepper, dicing them into small cubes. Strain the broth a second time for a clear, beautiful soup.

scenes.voice_over: Add peeled potatoes and diced red bell pepper to the strained broth. Boil, then simmer for 15 minutes, or until potatoes are almost tender.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of assorted fish fillets being added to the pot with potatoes and broth.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add your assorted fish fillets.  Simmer for 5-10 minutes, until cooked through but still flaky.

scenes.image_prompt: Whisking together egg and smetana in a bowl.  A ladle of hot soup being drizzled into the mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Whisk together an egg and smetana, then temper by slowly adding hot soup while whisking constantly.  This prevents the egg from curdling. Pour the tempered mixture into the soup and remove from heat.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped fresh lovage being stirred into the finished soup. Reserved cooked fish and vegetables are added as well.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the reserved fish pieces, diced vegetables, and fresh lovage. Season with salt, pepper, and white wine vinegar to taste.

scenes.image_prompt: Garlic cloves wrapped in foil, being placed in a preheated oven.

scenes.voice_over: Squeeze the roasted garlic into a bowl, add salt, and whisk in vegetable oil and water for a smooth sauce.

scenes.voice_over: Serve your Fisherman's Soup hot, with a dollop of roasted garlic sauce and crusty bread. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: Adjust the amount of vinegar to your liking for a tangier soup.

For a richer broth, roast the fish bones before making the stock.
Serve with crusty bread for dipping.

recipes.name: Flaky Halibut Salad with Fresh Herbs
ingredients: 1/4 cup good quality white wine vinegar
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Place the halibut fillets or steaks on a baking sheet.
Step 2: Drizzle the halibut with olive oil and season both sides with 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper.
Step 3: Roast for 20-25 minutes, or until the fish is firm and opaque throughout. Check for doneness by flaking with a fork.
Step 4: Let the cooked halibut cool at room temperature for about 30 minutes.
Step 5: Once cooled, remove and discard any skin and bones. Gently flake the fish into large pieces.
Step 6: In a large bowl, combine the flaked halibut, celery, red onion, fennel (if using), dill, lemon juice, vinegar, capers, and mayonnaise.
Step 7: Season the salad with an additional 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Mix gently until just combined.
Step 8: Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld. Taste and adjust seasoning as needed.
Step 9: Serve the salad chilled or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Broiled Indian-Spiced Fish
ingredients: Pinch of freshly ground black pepper
4 (6-ounce) fish fillets (swordfish, halibut, haddock, tuna, or salmon)
directions: Step 1: In a small bowl, combine the ginger, garlic, garam masala, cumin, turmeric, mustard powder, cayenne pepper, lemon juice, salt, and black pepper.
Step 2: Stir in about 1 tablespoon of warm water to form a very thick paste.
Step 3: Brush a baking sheet or broiler pan with 1 tablespoon of the melted butter. Place the fish fillets on the prepared pan.
Step 4: Cover both sides of the fish with the spice paste. Set aside to marinate for at least 15 minutes, but no more than 30 minutes.
Step 5: Preheat the broiler.
Step 6: Drizzle 2 tablespoons of the melted butter over the fish. Broil for 5 to 6 minutes, or until nicely browned.
Step 7: Turn the fish fillets over and drizzle with the remaining 2 tablespoons of melted butter. Broil for another 3 to 5 minutes, or until browned and cooked through.
Step 8: Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Fried Fish Cake Noodle Soup in Tomato Dashi
ingredients: 1 lb walleye fillet (or other firm white fish fillet), boneless and skinless
Freshly ground black pepper, to taste
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Fish: 1-2 hours before cooking, pat the fish fillets dry and place them in the freezer to firm up.

Step 2: Make the Dashi: Gently wipe the kombu kelp with a damp paper towel, avoiding removing the white powder.  Combine the kombu and water in a pot over medium heat. Bring to a bare simmer, then remove and discard the kombu.

Step 3: Infuse the Dashi: Add the katsuobushi to the simmering dashi. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat and let steep for 10 minutes. Strain the dashi through a fine-mesh sieve or cheesecloth, discarding the katsuobushi.

Step 4: Prepare the Tomato Broth: Return the dashi to the pot over medium heat. Add the quartered tomatoes and 1 1/2 tablespoons of fish sauce. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes.

Step 5: Make the Fish Cakes: While the dashi simmers, remove the fish from the freezer and cut into smaller chunks.  In a food processor, combine the fish, 1/4 cup dill, garlic, shallot, 4 teaspoons fish sauce, cornstarch, salt, and pepper. Process until a smooth and sticky paste forms.

Step 6: Knead and Shape the Fish Cakes: Transfer the fish paste to a bowl and knead for 2 minutes until smooth, dense, and springy. Form the fish paste into thin patties, about 1/2 tablespoon to 2 teaspoons each.

Step 7: Fry the Fish Cakes: Heat the olive oil in a frying pan over medium-high heat. Fry the fish cakes for about 2 minutes per side, until golden brown and crispy. Transfer to a plate lined with paper towels to drain.
Step 8: Cook the Noodles: Cook the vermicelli noodles according to package directions.

Step 9: Assemble the Soup: Taste the tomato broth and adjust seasoning as needed. Divide the cooked noodles among serving bowls. Top with the fried fish cakes, scallions, dill, and cilantro. Ladle the hot broth over the noodles and serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Fried Fish Cake Noodle Soup in Tomato Dashi. Style the soup in a rustic, off-white bowl, garnished with fresh dill sprigs and a drizzle of chili oil. recipes.name: Thai Fish Balls with Sweet Chili Sauce
ingredients: 500g firm white fish fillets (such as ling), coarsely chopped
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F).
Step 2: In a food processor, combine the fish, curry paste, brown sugar, lime rind, and fish sauce. Process until a coarse paste forms.
Step 3: Transfer the fish mixture to a bowl and stir in the sliced shallots.
Step 4: Roll 1 heaped tablespoon of the fish mixture into a ball and place on a plate. Repeat with the remaining fish mixture to make 18 balls.
Step 5: Heat half of the peanut oil in a large non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat.
Step 6: Add half of the fish balls to the pan and cook, turning often, for 5 minutes, or until golden brown.
Step 7: Transfer the cooked fish balls to a baking tray.
Step 8: Repeat steps 5 and 6 with the remaining oil and fish balls, reheating the pan between batches.
Step 9: Bake the fish balls in the preheated oven for 10 minutes, or until cooked through.
Step 10: Set the fish balls aside to cool slightly.
Step 11: Use a small amount of sweet chili sauce to attach a coriander leaf to each fish ball.
Step 12: Serve the fish balls with sweet chili sauce for dipping.

recipes.name: Classic Beer-Battered Fish and Chips
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, whisk together 1 cup of flour, salt, and paprika.
Step 2: Gradually whisk in 1 can of beer until the batter is smooth and thick enough to coat a spoon. Add more beer if needed, up to 2 cans total. The batter should be relatively thin.
Step 3: Set the batter aside for 10-15 minutes.
Step 4: Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pot to 375°F (190°C). Use a candy thermometer to monitor the temperature.
Step 5: Cut the cod fillets into 2-inch wide strips.
Step 6: Place the remaining 1/2 cup of flour in a shallow dish. Lightly dredge each fish strip in the flour, shaking off any excess.
Step 7: Carefully dip the floured fish strips into the batter, allowing any excess batter to drip off.
Step 8: Fry the fish in batches, 2 or 3 strips at a time, for 3-5 minutes, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 9: Remove the cooked fish from the oil and place them on a wire rack or paper towel-lined plate to drain.
Step 10: Serve immediately with french fries, tartar sauce, and malt vinegar.

recipes.name: Dad's Crispy Fish Batter
directions: Step 1: In a large bowl, sift together the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.
Step 2: Add the water (or beer) and whisk until smooth. If the batter is too thick, add a little more water, but be careful not to make it too thin.
Step 3: (Optional) If desired, add cornmeal, garlic powder, onion powder, and/or fish seasoning to the batter.
Step 4: Dip each fish fillet into the batter, ensuring it's fully coated but not excessively thick.
Step 5: Heat the oil in a deep fryer or large skillet to 350°F (175°C).
Step 6: Carefully place the battered fish into the hot oil and fry for 3-5 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 7: Remove the fish from the oil and place it on a wire rack or paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Step 8: Serve immediately with your favorite sides.

recipes.name: Crispy Air-Fried Fish Sticks
ingredients: 16 ounces frozen haddock fillets (or cod or pollock), thawed
Cooking spray or oil, for greasing
directions: Step 1: Gather all ingredients.
Step 2: Pat the thawed fish fillets dry with paper towels. Season lightly with 1/2 teaspoon of salt and 1/8 teaspoon of pepper.
Step 3: In a small bowl, whisk together the flour, Old Bay seasoning, remaining salt, and remaining pepper.
Step 4: In another bowl, whisk together the eggs and Dijon mustard.
Step 5: Coat each fish fillet in the flour mixture, then dip in the egg mixture, ensuring all sides are coated. Allow excess egg to drip off.
Step 6: Generously coat each fish fillet with panko breadcrumbs, pressing gently to adhere.
Step 7: Place the breaded fish sticks on a wire rack.  Refrigerate for at least 15 minutes to help the breading set (optional).
Step 8: Preheat the air fryer to 400°F (200°C). Lightly grease the air fryer basket with cooking spray or oil.
Step 9: Arrange half of the fish sticks in the air fryer basket in a single layer, ensuring space between each piece. Lightly spray the fish sticks with cooking spray (optional).
Step 10: Air fry for 8 minutes. Flip the fish sticks and continue cooking for another 4-8 minutes, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 11: Transfer the cooked fish sticks to a wire rack. Repeat with the remaining fish sticks.
Step 12: Serve immediately with lemon wedges and your choice of tartar sauce, remoulade, or ketchup.

Include a small bowl of tartar sauce and lemon wedges as props.  Shoot from a slightly overhead angle, emphasizing the texture and creating a warm, inviting mood.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the fish sticks cooking in the air fryer. After 8 minutes, show flipping them over. Show the finished, golden-brown fish sticks.
scenes.voice_over: Air fry for 8 minutes, then flip and cook for another 4-8 minutes, or until golden brown and cooked through. The internal temperature should reach 145°F (63°C).

scenes.image_prompt: Show the cooked fish sticks being transferred to a wire rack.
scenes.voice_over: Transfer the cooked fish sticks to a wire rack to cool slightly and maintain their crispiness.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished dish, golden-brown air-fried fish sticks served with lemon wedges, tartar sauce, remoulade, and ketchup on the side. The fish sticks should look crispy and inviting.
scenes.voice_over: Serve immediately with lemon wedges and your favorite dipping sauces like tartar sauce, remoulade, or ketchup. Enjoy your crispy, healthy, and delicious air-fried fish sticks!

cooking_tips: You can substitute other white fish fillets for haddock, cod, or pollock.
Refrigerating the breaded fish sticks for 15-30 minutes before air frying helps the breading adhere better and creates a crispier result.
Do not overcrowd the air fryer basket. Cook in batches to ensure even cooking.
The cooking time may vary depending on the thickness of the fish fillets and your air fryer model. Check for doneness by ensuring the fish is opaque and flakes easily with a fork.
For extra crispy fish sticks, lightly spray the tops of the fish sticks with cooking oil before air frying.

recipes.name: Thai Fish Curry (Kaeng Ped Pla) with Rice
ingredients: 2 tablespoons Thai soy sauce (or regular soy sauce/tamari)
1 Red chili pepper, seeded and chopped (or 1/4-1/2 teaspoon chili powder)
12 ounces Salmon fillets, skinned and cubed
1 (14-ounce) block Firm tofu, cubed (optional, instead of fish)
1 3/4 cups Coconut milk (or 1 can lite coconut milk)
1 stalk Lemongrass, white part only, finely chopped (or 1-2 teaspoons pre-minced lemongrass)
2 cups Jasmine rice (or brown basmati rice)
1 Red bell pepper, thinly sliced (or other vegetables)
3-4 tablespoons Mango, diced (or other tropical fruit, optional garnish)
directions: Step 1: Marinate the Protein: In a shallow non-metallic dish, combine the lime juice, half of the fish sauce, and the soy sauce. Add the chili pepper (or chili powder) and the fish (or tofu). Stir well to coat. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours, or preferably overnight. If the fish or tofu is not fully immersed, turn the pieces partway through marinating.
Step 2: Cook the Rice: Start cooking the rice according to package directions.
Step 3: Prepare the Curry: In a pan over medium heat, warm the red curry paste. Add the coconut milk, kaffir lime leaves, remaining fish sauce, and lemongrass. Simmer gently for 10-15 minutes.

Step 4: Add the Protein and Vegetables: Add the marinated fish (or tofu) and red bell pepper (or other vegetables) to the curry. Simmer for about 5 minutes, or until the fish/tofu and vegetables are cooked through.

Step 5: Adjust Seasoning and Serve: If needed, add a pinch or two of brown sugar to balance the flavors. Stir the chopped cilantro into the cooked rice. Serve the curry over the rice. Garnish with roasted pistachios and/or diced mango, if desired.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Thai Fish Curry (Kaeng Ped Pla) with rice.  Overhead shot slightly angled, shallow depth of field focusing on the fish and a vibrant red chili slice.  Dark wood background with rustic linen napkin partially underneath the bowl. Garnish with fresh cilantro and kaffir lime leaves. Lighting should be soft, natural, and directional to highlight the creamy texture of the curry and the flakiness of the fish. Use a minimalist style with dark, moody tones to create an upscale, dramatic image suitable for a food magazine.

video_script.title: Thai Fish Curry (Kaeng Ped Pla) with Rice
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and authentic Thai Fish Curry (Kaeng Ped Pla) with fragrant jasmine rice. This recipe is easy to follow and perfect for a weeknight dinner or a special occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a finished bowl of Thai Fish Curry with Rice, garnished with pistachios and mango. Steam gently rises from the curry. The background is slightly blurred, emphasizing the vibrant colors of the dish.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome to our kitchen! Today, we're diving into the vibrant flavors of Thailand with this amazing Fish Curry recipe, Kaeng Ped Pla, served with fluffy jasmine rice. It's packed with flavor and surprisingly easy to make.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table. Group related ingredients: fish and tofu, marinating ingredients, curry paste and coconut milk, rice, herbs and garnishes.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need:  For the marinade, we have lime, fish sauce, soy sauce, and chili.  For the curry itself, you'll need white fish, salmon, coconut milk, red curry paste, kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass, bell pepper, and of course, jasmine rice. For an extra touch, we'll garnish with cilantro, pistachios, and mango.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of fish and tofu being marinated in a dish with lime juice, fish sauce, soy sauce, and chili.  The marinade should visibly coat the protein.
scenes.voice_over: First, marinate the fish (or tofu) in a mixture of lime juice, fish sauce, soy sauce, and chili.  Make sure to coat the fish evenly. Cover and refrigerate for at least 1-2 hours, or even better, overnight. This allows the flavors to meld beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: Rice cooking in a pot on the stove, with steam rising.
scenes.voice_over: While the fish marinates, start cooking your jasmine rice according to the package directions.  Perfectly cooked rice is essential for soaking up all the delicious curry sauce.

scenes.image_prompt: Pan on the stove with red curry paste being warmed. Focus on the paste and its color.
scenes.voice_over: In a pan over medium heat, gently warm the red curry paste. This releases its aromatic oils and deepens the flavor of the curry.

scenes.image_prompt: Coconut milk, kaffir lime leaves, fish sauce, and lemongrass being added to the pan with the curry paste. Show the mixture simmering.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the coconut milk, kaffir lime leaves, the remaining fish sauce, and the lemongrass.  Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer and let it cook for 10-15 minutes, allowing the flavors to infuse.

scenes.image_prompt: Marinated fish and bell pepper being added to the simmering curry.
scenes.voice_over: Add the marinated fish and sliced bell peppers to the simmering curry. Cook for about 5 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and the vegetables are tender.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of a spoon stirring brown sugar into the curry, showing the texture and color of the dish.
scenes.voice_over: Now, taste the curry and adjust the seasoning with a pinch or two of brown sugar if needed. This balances the flavors beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: Cilantro being stirred into the cooked rice.
scenes.voice_over: Stir the chopped cilantro into your cooked rice. The fresh cilantro adds a lovely aroma and complements the curry perfectly.

scenes.image_prompt: Finished Thai Fish Curry served over cilantro rice, garnished with pistachios and mango. Show a serving spoon scooping some curry.
scenes.voice_over: Serve the fragrant Thai Fish Curry over the cilantro rice. Garnish with roasted pistachios and diced mango for added texture and flavor. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat coconut milk.
Adjust the amount of chili pepper to your preferred level of spiciness.
If using lemongrass stalks, bruise them lightly before adding to the curry to release more flavor.
Substitute other vegetables like bamboo shoots, zucchini, or green beans for the bell pepper.

recipes.name: Thai Fish Cakes
ingredients: 300g snapper or barramundi fillets, roughly chopped
2 small kaffir lime leaves, finely shredded
directions: Step 1: In a food processor or blender, combine the fish fillets and egg white. Pulse until coarsely chopped and roughly combined.
Step 2: Transfer the fish mixture to a large bowl. Add the red curry paste, fish sauce, kaffir lime leaves, and chopped green beans. Mix thoroughly until well combined.
Step 3: With damp hands, shape heaped tablespoonfuls of the mixture into small, flat cakes.
Step 4: Pour enough vegetable oil into a wok or deep fryer to reach a depth of 5cm. Heat over medium-high heat until a small piece of bread sizzles when dropped in (approximately 180°C).
Step 5: Carefully add 5-6 fish cakes to the hot oil and cook for 3 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Step 6: Remove the cooked fish cakes with a slotted spoon and transfer them to a plate lined with paper towels to drain excess oil. Repeat in batches with the remaining fish cakes.
Step 7: Serve hot with lime wedges and cucumber salad, if desired.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of crispy golden-brown Thai fish cakes, showcasing their textured surface. Use soft, diffused lighting to highlight the vibrant green flecks of beans and kaffir lime against the warm fish cake color. A shallow depth of field, focusing on the frontmost fish cake, creates a blurred background featuring a dark wooden board and a small dipping bowl of sweet chili sauce. Garnish with a single, vibrant kaffir lime leaf. The mood should be warm, inviting, and appetizing.

video_script.title: Crispy Thai Fish Cakes
video_script.description: Learn to make authentic Thai fish cakes with a crispy exterior and flavorful interior. This recipe is easy to follow and perfect for a quick weeknight meal or appetizer.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a plate of golden-brown Thai fish cakes, garnished with lime wedges and fresh cucumber salad. The fish cakes should look crispy and inviting.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making delicious Thai fish cakes. These crispy delights are packed with flavor and incredibly easy to make.

scenes.image_prompt: Show snapper or barramundi fillets, an egg white in a small bowl, red curry paste in a small bowl, and fish sauce in a small bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: fresh snapper or barramundi fillets, egg white, red curry paste, and fish sauce for that authentic Thai taste.

scenes.image_prompt: Show kaffir lime leaves, green beans, and a bowl of vegetable oil.
scenes.voice_over: We'll also use fragrant kaffir lime leaves, chopped green beans for a bit of crunch, and vegetable oil for frying.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the fish fillets and egg white being pulsed in a food processor until coarsely chopped.
scenes.voice_over: In a food processor, combine the fish fillets and egg white. Pulse until coarsely chopped, but not completely smooth.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the fish mixture in a bowl with the red curry paste, fish sauce, kaffir lime leaves, and green beans being mixed in.
scenes.voice_over: Transfer the fish mixture to a bowl. Add the red curry paste, fish sauce, kaffir lime leaves, and green beans. Mix thoroughly.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of hands shaping the fish cake mixture into small, flat cakes.
scenes.voice_over: With damp hands, shape the mixture into small, flat cakes about a tablespoon each.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the vegetable oil heating in a wok or deep fryer, with a small piece of bread sizzling when dropped in.
scenes.voice_over: Heat vegetable oil in a wok or deep fryer to 180°C. Test with a piece of bread; it should sizzle immediately.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the fish cakes frying in the hot oil, turning golden brown.
scenes.voice_over: Carefully add the fish cakes to the hot oil. Fry for about 3 minutes per side, until golden brown and cooked through.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the cooked fish cakes being removed from the oil and placed on a plate lined with paper towels.
scenes.voice_over: Remove the fish cakes and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished dish: golden-brown Thai fish cakes served with lime wedges and cucumber salad. Focus on the texture and vibrant colors.
scenes.voice_over: Serve your crispy Thai fish cakes hot with lime wedges and a refreshing cucumber salad. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For extra flavor, add a finely chopped stalk of lemongrass to the fish cake mixture.
If you don't have a wok, a large, deep frying pan can be used instead.
Ensure the oil is hot enough before adding the fish cakes to prevent them from becoming oily.
Don't overcrowd the wok or pan when frying the fish cakes, as this will lower the oil temperature and result in soggy fish cakes.

recipes.name: Spicy Fish Sandwiches with Homemade Tartar Sauce
ingredients: 4 white fish fillets (cod, halibut, tilapia, or similar)
Oil, butter, or ghee for cooking
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Spice Mix: In a small bowl, combine the paprika, thyme, black pepper, garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and a pinch of salt. Whisk or shake until well combined.
Step 2: Season the Fish: Pat the fish fillets dry with paper towels. Sprinkle both sides of each fillet generously with the spice mixture.
Step 3: Prepare the Tartar Sauce: In a separate bowl, whisk together the mayonnaise, minced dill pickle, dill pickle juice, Dijon mustard, and dried dill. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

Step 4: Cook the Fish: Heat a drizzle of oil, butter, or ghee in a skillet over medium heat. Working in batches to avoid overcrowding the pan, cook the fish fillets for 4-5 minutes on the first side. Flip and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes on the other side, or until the fish is opaque and cooked through. Adjust cooking time based on the thickness of the fillets.
Step 5: Assemble the Sandwiches: Spread tartar sauce on both halves of each bun. Place a cooked fish fillet on the bottom bun, top with lettuce, tomato slices, and the top bun.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture two spicy fish sandwiches on rustic wooden boards.  Flaky white fish, vibrant orange spice rub, and creamy tartar sauce should be clearly visible. Use a slightly overhead angle, showcasing the sandwich layers and textured buns.  Soft, diffused natural light highlights the ingredients.  A shallow depth of field focuses on the front sandwich, blurring the background of a simple linen napkin and scattered dill sprigs. Aim for a bright, inviting mood with warm tones.  Include a small bowl of extra tartar sauce garnished with a dill sprig.

cooking_tips: For extra flavor, marinate the fish in the spice mixture for 30 minutes before cooking.
If you prefer a spicier sandwich, add more cayenne pepper to the spice mix or use a spicy mayonnaise in the tartar sauce.
Serve the sandwiches with a side of French fries, coleslaw, or potato salad.

recipes.name: Steamed Barramundi Parcels with Thai Coconut-Chili Paste
ingredients: 1 long fresh red chili, finely chopped
3cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced
1 stalk lemongrass, white part only, finely chopped
directions: Step 1: Prepare the Steaming Setup: Place two pieces of banana leaf in a large metal steaming pan or bamboo steamer set over a saucepan or wok of simmering water. Steam, covered, for 30 seconds or until the leaves are soft and pliable. Set aside on a clean work surface. Repeat this process until all banana leaves are softened.
Step 2: Marinate the Fish: Place the fish portions in a glass dish, drizzle with lime juice, and season with salt.

Step 3: Make the Thai Paste: In a mortar and pestle, combine the chopped chili, peeled garlic, sliced ginger, and chopped lemongrass. Gently pound until a smooth paste forms. Add the coconut cream and fish sauce, stirring until well combined.

Step 4: Assemble the Parcels: Lay two softened banana leaves on the work surface in a cross shape. Place two pieces of marinated fish in the center and top with one-quarter of the spice paste. Fold the banana leaves over the fish to create a sealed parcel, securing each end with a toothpick. Repeat this process for the remaining fish and paste.
Step 5: Steam the Parcels: Place the fish parcels in the steaming basket. Steam, covered, for 8 minutes, or until the fish flakes easily with a fork.
Step 6: Serve: Divide the steamed fish parcels among serving plates. Serve hot with steamed rice and lime wedges.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture steamed barramundi parcels in vibrant banana leaves, nestled on a dark slate surface.  Focus sharply on the flaky fish, glistening with chili-coconut sauce, while the background softly blurs.  Use a slightly overhead angle to showcase the parcels' elegant folds.  Highlight the textures of the banana leaf and fish with directional, warm light. Garnish with fresh cilantro and lime wedges, suggesting a bright, tropical mood.  Include a glimpse of the vibrant chili paste in a small, rustic bowl.

scenes.voice_over: Let's gather our ingredients: fresh barramundi fillets, banana leaves for that authentic touch, lime, salt, and the aromatics for our Thai paste - chili, garlic, ginger, and lemongrass.  We'll also need coconut cream, fish sauce, and of course, steamed rice and lime wedges for serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of hands softening banana leaves by steaming them in a metal steamer over simmering water. Steam billows around the leaves.
scenes.voice_over: Start by softening the banana leaves.  Place two at a time in a steamer over simmering water for about 30 seconds. This makes them pliable for wrapping.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of fish fillets being drizzled with lime juice and seasoned with salt in a glass dish.
scenes.voice_over: Marinate the barramundi fillets with fresh lime juice and a pinch of salt.  This enhances the flavor and keeps the fish moist.

scenes.image_prompt: A mortar and pestle grinding the chili, garlic, ginger, and lemongrass. Show a close-up of the paste being formed.
scenes.voice_over: Now for the star of the show - the Thai paste.  Combine chili, garlic, ginger, and lemongrass in a mortar and pestle and grind to a smooth paste. Then mix in the coconut cream and fish sauce.

scenes.image_prompt: Demonstration of assembling the barramundi parcels. Show the cross shaped banana leaves, placing the fish and paste, and the folding process to create a secure parcel.
scenes.voice_over: Lay two softened banana leaves in a cross shape. Place the marinated fish in the center, top with the fragrant Thai paste, and fold the leaves to create a sealed parcel. Secure with toothpicks.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish parcels steaming in a bamboo steamer over simmering water. Focus on the steam rising and the parcels cooking.
scenes.voice_over: Steam the parcels for 8 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and flakes easily with a fork.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of a finished barramundi parcel being opened to reveal the steaming, flaky fish inside. Serve on a plate with rice and lime wedges.
scenes.voice_over: Carefully open the steaming parcels and serve immediately with fluffy steamed rice and a wedge of lime.  Each serving contains approximately 350 calories, 30 grams of protein, 25 grams of carbs, and 15 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: Use kitchen scissors to trim banana leaves to uniform size if needed. Ensure the water in the steamer remains at a gentle simmer throughout the cooking process to prevent overcooking or burning the banana leaf parcels. If fresh banana leaves are unavailable, parchment paper or aluminum foil can be substituted. Be sure to fold them tightly to create a good seal.

recipes.name: Blue-Eye Fish with Fennel and Tomato Spaghetti
ingredients: 1 fennel bulb, trimmed, halved, and thinly sliced (reserve fronds)
600g blue-eye fish steaks, skinned and cut into large cubes
directions: Step 1: Cook the bavette or spaghetti in a large pot of boiling salted water until al dente. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: While the pasta is cooking, heat the olive oil in a large frying pan over medium-high heat.
Step 3: Add the crushed garlic and sliced fennel to the pan and cook, stirring often, for 3 minutes, or until the fennel is softened.
Step 4: Pour in the fish stock and cook until it has reduced by half.
Step 5: Stir in the tomato pasta sauce and caster sugar. Season with salt and pepper.
Step 6: Bring the sauce to a boil, then add the cubed blue-eye fish.
Step 7: Reduce the heat to medium, spoon the sauce over the fish, cover the pan, and simmer for 3-4 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through and flakes easily with a fork.
Step 8: Divide the cooked pasta among serving plates. Top with the fish and tomato sauce. Sprinkle with the reserved chopped fennel fronds.
Step 9: Serve immediately with lemon wedges.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a plated Blue-Eye Fish with Fennel and Tomato Spaghetti, styled with a rustic, elegant feel.  Use natural, bright lighting to highlight the flaky fish and vibrant tomato sauce clinging to the bavette.  Focus on the fish, with a shallow depth of field blurring the background of textured linen and scattered fennel fronds. Compose from a slightly overhead angle, showcasing the twirled pasta and garnished with a lemon wedge. The mood should be inviting and appetizing.

scenes.text: Blue-Eye Fish with Fennel and Tomato Spaghetti
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making a flavorful and healthy Blue-Eye Fish with Fennel and Tomato Spaghetti. This dish is quick, easy, and perfect for a weeknight dinner.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table. Group ingredients: pasta, blue-eye fish, fennel bulb with fronds, canned tomato sauce, garlic, olive oil, fish stock, lemon, salt, and pepper.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: bavette or spaghetti, blue-eye fish steaks, fennel, garlic, olive oil, fish stock, tomato pasta sauce, sugar, salt, pepper, and lemon wedges.

scenes.image_prompt: A pot of boiling water with pasta being added to it.
scenes.voice_over: First, cook your pasta according to package directions in a large pot of salted boiling water until al dente. This usually takes about 8-10 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: A large frying pan with olive oil, crushed garlic, and sliced fennel cooking over medium-high heat. The fennel is softening and becoming translucent.
scenes.voice_over: While the pasta cooks, heat olive oil in a pan over medium-high heat. Add crushed garlic and sliced fennel. Sauté for about 3 minutes until softened.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish stock being poured into the pan with the sautéed fennel and garlic.
scenes.voice_over: Pour in the fish stock and let it reduce by half. This intensifies the flavor and creates a delicious base for our sauce.

scenes.image_prompt: Tomato pasta sauce and sugar being added to the pan. The sauce is simmering gently.
scenes.voice_over: Stir in the tomato pasta sauce and sugar. Season with salt and pepper to taste.  Bring the sauce to a gentle simmer.

scenes.image_prompt: Cubed blue-eye fish being added to the simmering tomato sauce. The fish is nestled into the sauce.
scenes.voice_over: Gently add the cubed blue-eye fish to the sauce. Make sure the fish is submerged, then cover and simmer for 3-4 minutes until cooked through.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the cooked fish being flaked with a fork to show it's cooked through.
scenes.voice_over: The fish is done when it flakes easily with a fork.

scenes.image_prompt: Cooked pasta being plated and topped with the blue-eye fish and tomato sauce. Fresh fennel fronds are being sprinkled on top.

scenes.image_prompt: Final shot of plated Blue-Eye Fish with Fennel and Tomato Spaghetti, served with a lemon wedge. Focus on the vibrant colors and textures of the dish.
scenes.voice_over: Serve immediately with a lemon wedge. Enjoy this light, flavorful, and satisfying meal!  This dish has approximately 500-600 calories per serving, with 40-50 grams of protein.

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use homemade fish stock.
If you don't have blue-eye fish, you can substitute with another firm white fish such as cod or snapper.
Don't overcook the fish, or it will become dry.
Taste and adjust the seasoning of the sauce as needed.

recipes.name: Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu
ingredients: 1 teaspoon Vadagam (or 1 teaspoon dried Fenugreek leaves)
directions: Step 1: Sauté the roughly chopped onion and tomato in 1 teaspoon of oil until softened and the raw smell dissipates. Transfer to a mixer.
Step 2: Add the grated coconut, fennel seeds, chili powder, coriander powder, and sautéed onion-tomato mixture to the mixer. Grind to a fine paste, adding a little water if needed.
Step 3: Soak the tamarind in 1/4 cup of warm water and extract the pulp. Set aside.
Step 4: Clean and wash the fish pieces. Pat dry and coat with turmeric powder. Set aside.
Step 5: Heat the remaining oil in a pot or kadai. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add curry leaves, chopped small onions, and garlic. Sauté for 3 minutes.
Step 6: Add the roughly chopped tomato and sauté until the raw smell disappears.
Step 7: Add the ground paste and a pinch of turmeric powder to the pot. Pour in 1/4 cup of water (adjust as needed for desired consistency) and salt. Bring to a boil and simmer for 15-20 minutes.
Step 8: Add the tamarind pulp and continue to simmer.

Step 9: Gently add the fish pieces to the curry. Be careful not to break them. Simmer until the fish is cooked through and the curry thickens. The oil will start to separate at the edges when the curry is done.
Step 10: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu in a rustic clay pot, emphasizing the rich, dark gravy clinging to the fish pieces.  Use shallow depth of field to focus on a succulent piece of fish in the foreground, with blurred background elements.  Incorporate warm, natural light to showcase the vibrant orange-brown hue of the kuzhambu and the texture of the coconut garnish. Style with a few curry leaves and a wedge of lime on the pot rim, against a dark, textured backdrop.  Aim for a moody, inviting atmosphere.

video_script.title: Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu: A Tangy South Indian Delight
video_script.description: Learn to make this delicious and flavorful Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu, a tangy and spicy South Indian curry.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a finished Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu served in a clay pot, garnished with coriander leaves. Steam rising from the curry. Focus on the rich color and texture of the curry.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu, a South Indian fish curry bursting with flavor. It's tangy, spicy, and utterly delicious.

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients arranged neatly on a wooden table: Vanjaram fish pieces, tamarind, coconut, onion, tomato, garlic, spices, curry leaves, and coriander leaves.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: Vanjaram fish, tamarind, coconut, onion, tomato, garlic, ginger, oil, fennel seeds, mustard seeds, chili powder, coriander powder, turmeric powder, vadagam or dried fenugreek leaves, curry leaves, coriander leaves, and salt.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped onion and tomato being sautéed in oil in a pan.
scenes.voice_over: First, sauté chopped onion and tomato in a teaspoon of oil until softened. This will enhance their flavor and create a base for our curry. Set this aside.

scenes.image_prompt: Coconut, fennel seeds, chili powder, coriander powder, and sautéed onion-tomato mixture being ground in a mixer.
scenes.voice_over: Now, grind coconut, fennel seeds, chili powder, coriander powder, and the sautéed onion-tomato mixture into a smooth paste.

scenes.image_prompt: Tamarind being soaked in warm water and pulp being extracted.
scenes.voice_over: Soak tamarind in warm water and extract the pulp. Tamarind adds the signature tanginess to our kuzhambu.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish pieces coated with turmeric powder.
scenes.voice_over: Clean and wash the fish pieces, pat them dry, and coat them with turmeric powder.

scenes.image_prompt: Mustard seeds spluttering in hot oil, followed by curry leaves, small onions, and garlic being sautéed.
scenes.voice_over: Heat the remaining oil, add mustard seeds and let them splutter. Add curry leaves, chopped small onions, and garlic. Sauté for 3 minutes

scenes.image_prompt: Ground paste being added to the pot with spices and water.
scenes.voice_over: Add the ground paste, a pinch of turmeric, water, and salt. Bring to a boil and simmer for 15-20 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Tamarind pulp being added to the simmering curry.
scenes.voice_over: Add the tamarind pulp and continue simmering.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish pieces being gently added to the curry.
scenes.voice_over: Gently add the fish pieces and simmer until cooked through.  The curry will thicken and the oil will start to separate when it's done.

scenes.image_prompt: Finished Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu garnished with coriander leaves and served with rice.
scenes.voice_over: Garnish with coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice. Enjoy your delicious Vanjaram Fish Kuzhambu!

cooking_tips: Adjust the amount of chili powder to your preference.
For a richer flavor, use coconut milk instead of water.
If vadagam is unavailable, substitute with dried fenugreek leaves.

recipes.name: Pan-Seared Fish with Thai Coleslaw
ingredients: 4 firm white fish fillets (e.g., cod, haddock, or snapper), skin and bones removed
directions: Step 1: Blanch the snow peas in a saucepan of boiling water until tender-crisp (about 1-2 minutes). Immediately plunge into iced water to stop cooking and maintain their vibrant green color. Drain well and slice diagonally in half. Set aside.
Step 2: Lightly brush the fish fillets with peanut oil.
Step 3: Heat a non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat.
Step 4: Add the fish fillets to the hot pan and cook for 3 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.  Cook in batches if necessary to avoid overcrowding the pan.
Step 5: Remove the cooked fish from the pan and keep warm.
Step 6: In a large bowl, combine the shredded wombok, sliced carrots, blanched snow peas, and fresh coriander leaves.
Step 7: In a small bowl, whisk together the lime juice, fish sauce, brown sugar, and remaining peanut oil until the sugar dissolves completely.
Step 8: Pour the dressing over the wombok mixture and toss gently until well combined.
Step 9: To serve, flake the cooked fish into large pieces and arrange over the Thai coleslaw. Serve immediately with sweet chili sauce, if desired.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture pan-seared white fish fillets atop vibrant Thai coleslaw.  Use a dark, textured backdrop and natural, bright lighting to emphasize the crisp slaw and flaky fish.  Style with scattered snow peas, fresh coriander sprigs, and a lime wedge.  Shoot from a slightly overhead angle with a shallow depth of field, focusing on the fish's sear.  Aim for a fresh, inviting mood, highlighting the textures and contrasting colors of the dish.  Consider incorporating subtle reflections and dark, matte props like chopsticks and a small ceramic bowl.

video_script.title: Pan-Seared Fish with Thai Coleslaw
video_script.description: A quick and healthy weeknight meal featuring flaky pan-seared fish on a bed of vibrant Thai coleslaw.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished dish: Flaky pan-seared white fish nestled on a vibrant bed of Thai coleslaw with pops of green from the snow peas, orange from the carrots, and white from the wombok.  Sweet chili sauce drizzled artistically over the fish.
scenes.voice_over: Looking for a healthy and flavorful weeknight dinner?  This Pan-Seared Fish with Thai Coleslaw is ready in under 30 minutes!

scenes.image_prompt: Ingredients laid out on a wooden cutting board: Fresh white fish fillets, snow peas, wombok, carrots, coriander, lime, and a small bowl of fish sauce.
scenes.voice_over: Let's gather our ingredients.  We'll need firm white fish fillets, snow peas, wombok, carrots, fresh coriander, lime juice, fish sauce, brown sugar, and peanut oil.

scenes.image_prompt: Snow peas being blanched in boiling water in a saucepan.
scenes.voice_over: First, blanch the snow peas in boiling water for 1-2 minutes until tender-crisp. Then, plunge them into iced water to preserve their color and stop the cooking process.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish fillets being brushed with peanut oil.
scenes.voice_over: Lightly brush the fish fillets with peanut oil. This will help create a beautiful golden crust.

scenes.image_prompt: Fish fillets searing in a hot non-stick pan.
scenes.voice_over: Heat a non-stick frying pan over medium-high heat.  Sear the fish fillets for about 3 minutes per side, until golden brown and cooked through. Avoid overcrowding the pan; cook in batches if necessary.

scenes.image_prompt: Shredded wombok, sliced carrots, blanched snow peas, and coriander in a large bowl.
scenes.voice_over: While the fish is cooking, prepare the coleslaw. In a large bowl, combine the shredded wombok, sliced carrots, blanched and halved snow peas, and fresh coriander leaves.

scenes.image_prompt: Lime juice, fish sauce, brown sugar, and peanut oil being whisked together in a small bowl.
scenes.voice_over: In a separate bowl, whisk together the lime juice, fish sauce, brown sugar, and remaining peanut oil until the sugar is fully dissolved.

scenes.image_prompt: Dressing being poured over the coleslaw mixture and tossed gently.
scenes.voice_over: Pour the dressing over the coleslaw and toss gently to combine.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of flaked fish being arranged over the Thai coleslaw. A small bowl of sweet chili sauce is placed next to the dish.
scenes.voice_over: To serve, flake the cooked fish and arrange it over the Thai coleslaw. Serve immediately with a side of sweet chili sauce, if desired.

scenes.image_prompt: The finished dish, Pan-Seared Fish with Thai Coleslaw, plated beautifully and ready to be enjoyed.
scenes.voice_over: This Pan-Seared Fish with Thai Coleslaw is a delicious and healthy meal.  Enjoy!  Per serving, it has approximately 300 calories, 25 grams of protein, 20 grams of carbs, and 15 grams of fat.

cooking_tips: For best results, use fresh, high-quality fish fillets.
Don't overcook the fish, as it will become dry. It should be opaque and flake easily with a fork.
Adjust the amount of fish sauce and brown sugar in the dressing to suit your taste.
If you don't have peanut oil, you can substitute vegetable oil or canola oil.
Serve with steamed rice or quinoa for a complete meal.

recipes.name: Seared Turmeric Fish with Rice Noodles (Chả Cá)
ingredients: 12 ounces catfish fillets, or salmon, or other firm white fish
3 tablespoons galangal or ginger juice, freshly grated
directions: Step 1: Marinate the Fish: In a shallow dish, combine buttermilk, turmeric, galangal/ginger juice, and shrimp paste. Add the fish fillets, ensuring they are fully coated. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight.
Step 2: Prepare the Noodles: Cook rice noodles according to package directions. Drain, rinse with cold water, and divide among four serving bowls.
Step 3: Assemble the Bowls: Add chopped romaine lettuce, Thai basil, mint, perilla (if using), and roasted peanuts to the noodle bowls.

Step 4: Sear the Fish: Pat the marinated fish fillets dry with paper towels. Heat vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Sear the fish for 2-3 minutes per side, or until cooked through and flaky. Be careful not to break the fillets.

Step 5: Garnish and Serve: Place the seared fish on top of the noodles.  In the same skillet, quickly sauté the chopped dill and green onions until fragrant. Sprinkle over the fish. Serve immediately with fish sauce, shrimp sauce, and lime wedges on the side for guests to adjust to their liking.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a stunning overhead shot of seared turmeric fish (Chả Cá) with rice noodles.  Emphasize the vibrant yellow turmeric crust on the fish against the white noodles.  Use natural, bright lighting to highlight the textures. Incorporate fresh dill, green onions, and chopped romaine lettuce as garnishes.  A dark, rustic wooden background and light linen napkins would complement the dish. Shallow depth of field, focusing on the fish, creates a soft, inviting mood.  Include chopsticks placed artfully within the frame.

video_script.title: Seared Turmeric Fish with Rice Noodles (Chả Cá)

scenes.voice_over: Combine these ingredients in a dish, coat the fish thoroughly, and let it marinate in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.

scenes.image_prompt: Dried rice noodles, a pot of boiling water, and a colander.
scenes.voice_over: While the fish marinates, cook the rice noodles according to package directions. Rinse with cold water and set aside.

scenes.image_prompt: A bowl with cooked rice noodles, chopped romaine lettuce, Thai basil, mint, perilla, and roasted peanuts.
scenes.voice_over: Now, let's assemble our bowls. Add cooked noodles, chopped romaine, Thai basil, mint, perilla if using, and roasted peanuts.

scenes.voice_over: In the same skillet, quickly sauté some chopped dill and green onions.

scenes.voice_over: Customize your Chả Cá with fish sauce, shrimp sauce, and a squeeze of lime. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a stronger turmeric flavor, use fresh turmeric root, grated.
If you can't find galangal, ginger is a good substitute.
Don't overcook the fish, or it will become dry.
Adjust the amount of fish sauce and shrimp sauce to your preference.

recipes.name: Steamed Fish with Green Beans (No Steamer Required)
ingredients: 1 lemon, juiced and cut into wedges
directions: Step 1: Season the fish fillets: Pat the fish fillets dry with paper towels. Place them on a plate slightly larger than the pan you'll use to cook the green beans. Season both sides with salt and pepper, then drizzle with the juice of half a lemon.
Step 2: Prepare the green beans: Trim the ends off the green beans. Place the green beans in a pan with the salted water.
Step 3: Create the steamer: Place the plate with the fish fillets on top of the pan of green beans. Cover the plate tightly with a lid to create a makeshift steamer.

Step 4: Steam the fish and green beans: Bring the water in the pan to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to a simmer. Steam for 5-8 minutes, or until the green beans are tender-crisp and the fish is cooked through. If the fish fillets are thick, gently flip them halfway through the cooking time.

Step 5: Finish and serve: Drain the green beans. Carefully pour any accumulated juices from the fish plate over the green beans and toss gently. Transfer the steamed fish to serving plates. Drizzle with extra-virgin olive oil and serve alongside the green beans, lemon wedges, and crusty bread.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture two glistening, skinless fish fillets nestled on a bed of vibrant green beans, glistening with olive oil.  A halved lemon rests alongside, cut side down, with a few scattered wedges.  Shallow depth of field focuses sharply on the fish, highlighting its flaky texture.  Bright, natural light from the side creates gentle shadows.  A rustic linen napkin and crusty bread slice subtly complement the scene.  Shoot from a slightly elevated angle to showcase the steam's gentle wisps and the dish's fresh, healthy appeal.

video_script.title: Steamed Fish with Green Beans (No Steamer Required)
video_script.description: A quick and healthy weeknight meal: learn how to steam delicious fish and green beans without a steamer!

scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: two skinless fish fillets, fresh green beans, a lemon, extra-virgin olive oil, salt, pepper, water, and some crusty bread for serving.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of fish fillets being seasoned with salt, pepper, and lemon juice.
scenes.voice_over: First, pat the fish fillets dry and season both sides with salt and pepper. Then, drizzle with the juice of half a lemon.

scenes.image_prompt: Green beans being trimmed and placed in a pan with water.
scenes.voice_over: Trim the ends off your green beans and place them in a pan with half a cup of salted water.

scenes.image_prompt: Plate of seasoned fish fillets being placed on top of the pan with green beans, then covered with a lid.
scenes.voice_over: Now, place the plate with the seasoned fish on top of the green beans. Cover tightly with a lid to create our makeshift steamer.

scenes.image_prompt: Pan on the stove with steam escaping from under the lid. Graphic overlay indicating high heat then reducing to a simmer.
scenes.voice_over: Bring the water to a boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer and steam for 5 to 8 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of the fish being checked for doneness with a fork, showing it flaking easily.
scenes.voice_over: The fish is done when it flakes easily with a fork. If your fillets are thick, flip them halfway through.

scenes.voice_over: Drain the green beans and toss them with any juices from the fish plate.  Drizzle the fish with olive oil.

scenes.voice_over: Serve the fish alongside the green beans, lemon wedges, and crusty bread. This dish is about 250 calories per serving with 25 grams of protein. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For best results, use a plate made of heat-resistant material, such as ceramic or glass.
Adjust the steaming time depending on the thickness of your fish fillets. The fish should be opaque and flake easily with a fork when cooked through.
If you don't have fresh green beans, frozen green beans can be substituted. Add them to the pan frozen and increase the cooking time as needed.

recipes.name: Mediterranean Fish Soup (Kakavia)
directions: Step 1: In a large pot, combine the dusky grouper, scorpion fish, crabs, and shrimps.
Step 2: Add the pimentos, parsley, celery, bay leaves, olive oil, and saffron.
Step 3: Season with salt and pepper, then add enough cold water to just cover the fish (approximately 1800ml).
Step 4: Cover the pot and bring to a boil over high heat.
Step 5: Reduce heat to medium and simmer for 30 minutes.
Step 6: Carefully remove the dusky grouper and scorpion fish using a slotted spoon and transfer them to a large platter.
Step 7: Strain the fish stock into a separate container, discarding the solids.
Step 8: Return the fish stock to the pot. Add the carrots, zucchinis, onions, and potatoes. Season with salt and pepper.
Step 9: Cover the pot and bring to a boil over high heat.
Step 10: Reduce heat to medium and simmer for 25-30 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.

Step 11: While the vegetables are cooking, carefully remove the flesh from the cooked dusky grouper and scorpion fish, discarding the bones and skin. Transfer the fish to a warm platter, cover, and keep warm in a low oven.
Step 12: Once the vegetables are tender, remove the pot from the heat.
Step 13: Using an immersion blender, purée the soup until smooth.
Step 14: For a smoother texture, pass the puréed soup through a fine-mesh sieve into another pot.
Step 15: Stir in the lemon juice and adjust seasoning as needed.
Step 16: Serve the soup in bowls, drizzled with a few drops of olive oil and freshly ground black pepper.
Step 17: Dress the reserved fish with olive oil and lemon juice and serve alongside the soup.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a rustic, inviting image of Kakavia. Style the soup in a light-colored, shallow bowl, garnished with fresh parsley sprigs. Position two cooked shrimps and a crab claw artfully on top. Utilize natural, bright lighting to highlight the orange hue of the soup and the textures of the seafood.  Employ a slightly overhead angle with a shallow depth of field, focusing sharply on the seafood garnish. The background should be a textured, neutral surface with subtle Mediterranean props like olive oil and saffron threads. Aim for a warm, comforting mood.

recipes.name: Baked White Fish with Aromatic Vegetables
ingredients: 1.5-2.5 pounds white fish fillets (haddock, tilapia, cod, or flounder)
6 ounces minari (water dropwort), cut into 2-inch pieces (or 1/2 green bell pepper or a few green chili peppers)
4 ounces fresh shiitake mushrooms, thinly sliced
1/2 cup dashima (dried kelp broth) or other flavored broth
directions: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).
Step 2: Rinse the fish fillets and pat dry with paper towels. Season with salt and pepper. Set aside.
Step 3: Remove seeds and ribs from bell peppers. Thinly slice the peppers.
Step 4: Cut minari into 2-inch pieces. Thinly slice mushrooms and onion.
Step 5: Heat a little oil in a pan over medium-high heat. Stir-fry the onion until translucent, seasoning lightly with salt and pepper. Transfer to a plate.
Step 6: Stir-fry the bell peppers separately for 1-2 minutes each until slightly softened but still crisp. Transfer to the plate.
Step 7: In a small bowl, whisk together dashima broth, soy sauce, minced garlic, grated ginger, and lemon juice.
Step 8: Dredge each fish fillet in flour, shaking off any excess.

Step 9: Lightly oil a baking dish. Spread 1/4 of the stir-fried vegetables in the bottom of the dish. Arrange half of the floured fish fillets over the vegetables in a single layer. Top with another 1/4 of the vegetables and drizzle with half of the sauce.
Step 10: Arrange the remaining fish fillets over the vegetables and drizzle with the remaining sauce. Cover loosely with aluminum foil.
Step 11: Bake for 20 minutes.
Step 12: Remove from the oven and arrange the remaining vegetables over the fish. Cover again with aluminum foil and bake for another 10 minutes.
Step 13: Serve immediately.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a baked white fish fillet nestled amongst vibrant red, yellow bell peppers, minari, shiitake mushrooms, and onions, glistening with dashima broth.  Use a slightly overhead, close-up angle with a shallow depth of field, focusing sharply on the fish's flaky texture and the glistening vegetables.  Employ soft, natural light to highlight the dish's freshness.  A dark, rustic wooden background and simple white ceramic serving dish will enhance the earthy tones. Garnish with a sprinkle of fresh minari and a drizzle of broth for added visual appeal.  Aim for a warm, inviting mood.

recipes.name: Broiled Salmon with Indian Spices
directions: Step 1: Preheat broiler to high.
Step 2: In a small bowl, combine ground ginger, garam masala, ground coriander, ground turmeric, salt, and red pepper.
Step 3: Rub the spice mixture evenly over the salmon fillets.
Step 4: Lightly coat a broiler pan or baking sheet with cooking spray.
Step 5: Place the seasoned salmon fillets on the prepared pan.
Step 6: Cover the pan with aluminum foil and broil for 7 minutes.
Step 7: Remove the foil and continue broiling for another 4 minutes, or until the salmon is cooked through and flakes easily with a fork.
Step 8: Serve the broiled salmon with Nutty Basmati Rice.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a broiled salmon fillet seasoned with vibrant Indian spices, nestled on a bed of nutty basmati rice.  Use a slightly overhead, angled shot with shallow depth of field, focusing on the flaky texture of the salmon.  A dark, rustic backdrop with warm, directional light should emphasize the rich colors. Garnish with fresh cilantro and a lime wedge.  Include a glimpse of the spice blend in a small bowl in the background. Aim for a warm, inviting mood with a touch of elegance.

video_script.title: Broiled Salmon with Indian Spices
video_script.description: A quick and flavorful salmon dish infused with aromatic Indian spices, served with nutty basmati rice.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of perfectly broiled salmon fillets on a plate with a side of nutty basmati rice. The salmon is flaky and slightly charred, glistening with spices. Steam rises gently from the dish.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making a delicious and healthy meal: Broiled Salmon with Indian Spices. It's quick, easy, and packed with flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: Display of the measured spices: ground ginger, garam masala, ground coriander, ground turmeric, salt, and red pepper, arranged in small bowls.
scenes.voice_over: For our aromatic spice blend, we'll need ground ginger, garam masala, coriander, turmeric, salt, and a pinch of red pepper for a touch of heat.

scenes.image_prompt: Four salmon fillets laid out on a cutting board.  A small bowl of mixed spices is next to the salmon. A hand is rubbing the spice mixture onto the salmon fillets.
scenes.voice_over: Combine these spices in a bowl. Now, generously rub this fragrant mixture all over your salmon fillets, ensuring they are evenly coated.

scenes.image_prompt: A hand spraying a baking sheet/broiler pan with cooking spray.
scenes.voice_over: Lightly coat your broiler pan or baking sheet with cooking spray to prevent sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: The seasoned salmon fillets are placed on the prepared baking sheet.
scenes.voice_over: Place the seasoned salmon fillets on the prepared pan. We’ll cover it with aluminum foil and preheat the broiler to high.

scenes.image_prompt: The baking sheet with salmon, covered in foil, goes into the preheated broiler. Display timer set for 7 minutes.
scenes.voice_over: Place the pan in the preheated broiler, covered, for 7 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: The foil is removed from the baking sheet after 7 minutes.  A hand removes the foil, revealing the salmon.
scenes.voice_over: After 7 minutes, remove the foil and continue broiling for another 4 minutes, or until the salmon is cooked through.

scenes.image_prompt: A fork flakes a piece of cooked salmon to show doneness.
scenes.voice_over: The salmon is ready when it flakes easily with a fork.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of the finished dish: broiled salmon fillets plated with a generous serving of nutty basmati rice, garnished with fresh herbs (like cilantro or parsley).
scenes.voice_over: Serve the flavorful broiled salmon with nutty basmati rice. Garnish with some fresh herbs if you like. This dish is a complete and satisfying meal with approximately 250-300 calories, 30-35 grams of protein, and only 10-15 grams of fat per serving. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, marinate the salmon in the spice mixture for at least 30 minutes before broiling.
To ensure even cooking, make sure the salmon fillets are similar in thickness.

The cooking time may vary depending on the thickness of the fillets and the strength of your broiler. Use a meat thermometer to check for doneness; the internal temperature of the salmon should reach 145°F (63°C).
Serve with a side of steamed vegetables or a fresh salad for a complete meal.
If you don't have a broiler, you can bake the salmon in a preheated oven at 400°F (200°C) for 12-15 minutes, or until cooked through.
